This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-12-12 17:30:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/30959). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

As of December 11, 2024, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), report [58 confirmed human cases of H5 avian influenza](https://www.cdc.gov/bird-flu/situation-summary/index.html) in the United States. So far 56 of these cases have been connected to exposure from cattle or poultry, though the exposure source of two of these cases is unknown.

The spread of H5 avian influenza among birds and cattle and its spread to humans has [raised concerns](https://www.today.com/health/disease/bird-flu-pandemic-rcna183174) that it could turn into another pandemic. However, as of December 11, 2024, CDC's [summary of the current situation](https://www.cdc.gov/bird-flu/situation-summary/index.html) states the following:

> * Person-to-person spread: None
> * Current public health risk: Low

In the United States, declarations of a [public health emergency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_health_emergency_(United_States)) (PHE) can allow the government to [take a number of emergency preparedness and response actions](https://aspr.hhs.gov/legal/PHE/Pages/phe-qa.aspx). [According to the US Department of Health and Human Services](https://aspr.hhs.gov/legal/PHE/pages/default.aspx) (HHS):

>The Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) may, under section 319 of the Public Health Service (PHS) Act determine that: a) a disease or disorder presents a public health emergency; or b) that a public health emergency, including significant outbreaks of infectious disease or bioterrorist attacks, otherwise exists. 

The HHS maintains [a page of all prior PHE declarations](https://aspr.hhs.gov/legal/PHE/pages/default.aspx) since August of 2005, including for the four disease outbreaks designated in that period of [H1N1](https://aspr.hhs.gov/legal/PHE/Pages/h1n1-26Apr2009.aspx), [Zika](https://aspr.hhs.gov/legal/PHE/Pages/zika-pr.aspx), [COVID-19](https://aspr.hhs.gov/legal/PHE/Pages/2019-nCoV.aspx), and [Mpox](https://aspr.hhs.gov/legal/PHE/Pages/monkeypox-4Aug22.aspx), each of which was renewed at least once.

question_details.fine_print:
* To qualify, a public health emergency must be declared which names H5 avian influenza in some form. This could include naming H5 or any subtype of H5, or any name given to H5 or highly pathogenic avian influenza that, in the judgment of Metaculus, encompasses H5 or any subtype of H5. Announcements of public health emergencies are typically [posted at the HHS website](https://aspr.hhs.gov/legal/PHE/pages/default.aspx).
* The intention is for this question to resolve based on any public health emergency declared by the HHS. Therefore, this question does not have additional requirements beyond the declaration (for example, human-to-human transmission is not required).
* In the event the law is changed such that a non-HHS agency is expected to be responsible for declaring such emergencies, Metaculus may clarify or annul this question.
* The state or territory designated for the public health emergency is immaterial, any declaration will count.

**H5N1 Avian Influenza: How Dangerous Is It? Risks to Humans, Animals, and the Pandemic Threat**
The highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus continues to spread across wild bird populations in Europe, particularly among cranes and waterfowl such as ducks and geese, according to the Friedrich-Loeffler-Institut (FLI). However, a single mutation, such as Q226L, could significantly enhance its human receptor-binding capacity. The virus remains non-transmissible between humans and requires further mutations to become a human pandemic threat. A key concern is the potential for genetic reassortment if a human is co-infected with H5N1 and seasonal influenza, as seen in the 2009 H1N1 pandemic.
